IRM 2.8.8, dated December 07, 2020, is superseded.

This IRM is intended for the general use of IDRS system personnel from all four Business Operating Divisions (W&I, SB/SE, LB&I and TE/GE) and Appeals accessing the Audit Information Management System.
AIMS Command Codes AMNON, AMTIN, AMBLK, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB
Command Code AMNON Command Code AMNOND Command Code AMTIN
Command Code AMBLK Command Code AMBLK Command Code AMFRZ Command Code AMREQ Command Code AMLAB
AIMS Command Codes AMNON, AMTIN, AMBLK, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB 2.8.8

) This IRM section provides the instructions for the Audit Information Manage- ment System (AIMS) command code AMNON, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB. AMNON processes EXAM.TEGE request for a Non Master File (NMF) return. Establishes a full record on AIMS for speciﬁc account tat is not a Master File. Generated

record to be used in operinga programs to generate charge outs for NMF cases. AMNOND will delete the Aims Account from the data base. AMFRZ will set an AIMS freeze code on an account which prevents closing of that account. AMREQ is used to cause Master File to send an update record to AIMS Weekend processing. This update record includes most ﬁelds on the AIMS data base. It generates TC
transaction (F/). AMLAB generates realtime lables for returns on AIMS. Generated Status-Change-Label Records (FP).

This IRM section provides the instructions for the Audit Information Manage- ment System (AIMS) command code AMNON, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB. AMNON processes EXAM.TEGE request for a Non Master File (NMF) return. Establishes a full record on AIMS for speciﬁc account tat is not a Master File. Generated 5546 record to be used in operinga programs to generate charge outs for NMF cases. AMNOND will delete the Aims Account from the data base. AMFRZ will set an AIMS freeze code on an account which prevents closing of that account. AMREQ is used to cause Master File to send an update record to AIMS Weekend processing. This update record includes most ﬁelds on the AIMS data base. It generates TC429 transaction (F/). AMLAB generates realtime lables for returns on AIMS. Generated Status-Change-Label Records (FP).
List of terms and deﬁnitions used throughout this IRM Section
2.8.8.1.1(12-19-2017) Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms
Acronym Deﬁnitions PBC Primary Business Code EGC Employee Group Code TIN Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number

) CC AMNON is used to establish NMF records on AIMS. This command code will accept as input the data necessary to establish a return on AIMS with a source of N or D. File Source N, indicated by EIN or SSN input format, is used when the NMF TIN is known. File Source D is input when the correct TIN is unknown or unavailable. After the data has been validated, the return will be established on AIMS. (
) The input documents for CC AMNON are as follows: a. Form
-D, Examination Request - ERCS (Examination Return Control System) Users. b. Form
, Examination Request for Non-Master File for Examination Division. c. Form
, TE/GE NMF Request - EO, EP and GE Divisions. (
) A Form
, Examination Return Charge-out, and labels will be printed at service center during the weekly processing for distribution to the originator. (
) CC AMNOND allows for real-time deletion of a previously-established NMF record if all validity/consistency checks are met. See Exhibit
for detailed procedures.
A Form 5546, Examination Return Charge-out, and labels will be printed at the service center during the weekly processing for distribution to the originator.
2.8 Audit Information Management System (AIMS)
Error Messages - If the data entered did not pass validity or consistency checks, a message will be displayed.

If a ﬁeld did not pass a validity check, the position following the incorrect ﬁeld will have an asterisk and the message “ CORRECT INVALID DATA” will de displayed. If a ﬁeld did not pass a consistency check the message “CORRECT IN- CONSISTENT DATA” will be displayed on line

CC AMTIN7 will only be used to obtain temporary taxpayer identiﬁcation numbers. See Exhibit 2.8.8-3 for input and output displays and procedures.
Command Code AMBLK displays data stored by the computer for NMF Cases in response to closing command codes. It is an auxiliary Command Code used after the following command codes:
AIMS Command Codes AMNON, AMTIN, AMBLK, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB 2.8.8

a. CC AMSOC - to display data stored by the computer for a particular terminal for a short closing. b. CC AMCLS (O, E, A, P, F) - to display data stored by the computer for particular terminal for a long closing. (

) Command Code AMBLK displays data stored for closing, however it does differentiate between two similar Command Codes with a different sixth digit (i.e. AMSOC/AMSOCA). Only the ﬁrst ﬁve digits of Command Code are refer- enced in this section and it is to be understood that if Command Code AMBLK is to be used after CC AMSOCA, instructions for CC AMSOC should be used.
) Command Code AMBLK Error Messages (
) If any errors are encountered one of the following messages may appear on line

of output display: BLOCK NOT STARTED This terminal has been cleared but a new block has not been started since there has been no TIN, MFT, Tax DLN stored in this terminal. I / O ERROR Input/Output error while trying to access information stored in this terminal. Please recheck your entries and try again.

Command Code AMBLK displays data stored for closing, however it does not differentiate between two similar Command Codes with a different sixth digit (i.e. AMSOC/AMSOCA). Only the ﬁrst ﬁve digits of Command Code are refer- enced in this section and it is to be understood that if Command Code AMBLK is to be used after CC AMSOCA, instructions for CC AMSOC should be used.
BLOCK NOT STARTED
This terminal has been cleared but a new block has not been started since there has been no TIN, MFT, Tax DLN stored in this terminal.
Input/Output error while trying to access information stored in this terminal. Please recheck your entries and try again.

) This Command Code, used with deﬁner “S”, sets the a Specialized Freeze Code on AIMS which will prevent a case from closing or updating. When used with deﬁner “R” it will remove the Specialized Freeze Code speciﬁed on the screen. See Exhibit
) Input may be a single line or batch. If batch, up to
lines may be input. A correct entry will display OK in position
, an incorrect entry will display ** with a corresponding error message in line
An entry of DR on top if the two asterisks will bypass the line. (
) The following error messages are for CC AMFRZ:
2.8 Audit Information Management System (AIMS)
CANNOT INPUT IMF WITH BMF/EPMF/NMF ON SAME SCREEN
Cannot release AIMS SPECIALIZED FREEZE CODE X or U if not equal to BANKRUPTCY FREEZE CODE
FIRST 2 DIGITS OF THE TAX PERIOD MUST BE 19 OR 20
The century digits of the Tax Period must be the ﬁrst two characters of the Tax Period and must be 19 or 20
FREEZE CODE bA THRU bZ OR 1 THRU 9 OR 10 THRU 99 BE ENTERED
AMFRZR: freeze code “bA” thru“bZ” or 1 thru 99 must be entered on the screen.
FREEZE CODE XX ALREADY POSTED
There is already a Freeze Code on AIMS, it must be removed before posting a new one. (XX is the freeze code on the record)
Input matches on TIN, F/S, MFT, Tax period but Check Digit is not correct for TIN

Audit Information Management System (AIMS)
) Command Code AMREQ (
) The input of this command code for an account on the Taxpayer Information File (TIF) database will cause a transaction (TC
) to be generated to the Master File to bring back to the data base current update information such as freeze conditions and entity information. (
) This command code would normally be used only on rare occasions where the data base record does not contain the latest update data.
) Command Code AMREQ (
) The following error messages are for Command Code AMREQ:
This command code would normally be used only on rare occasions where the data base record does not contain the latest update data.

The TIN has been changed. The new TIN and Check Digit/Name Control is displayed in message.

) CC AMLAB is used to obtain additional Status Change, Name and Address Exam Labels for a return established on AIMS. These labels (a total of eighteen) will be printed during overnight processing at the Service Center. The right-most (top) label will be identiﬁed by having “AUDIT LABEL” printed on middle line (left) and the PBC, EGC and Status Code that were input on CC AMLAB will be printed on the right side of the label.
AIMS Command Codes AMNON, AMTIN, AMBLK, AMFRZ, AMREQ and AMLAB 2.8.8

CC AMTIN7 Output Display If CC AMTIN7 has been entered and there are no errors encountered, the generated “TIN” will be displayed on line 1, beginning in position 8.
The TIN to be created beginning in position 8, will be made up as follows:
Terminal District Office or Service Center Code.
These 6 - digits are obtained by the computer from a permanent record con- sisting of a six-digit number, which is incremented by one (1) each time it is used.

After the DLN appears on screen in response to CC AMBLK, the operator will depress the “PRINT” key which will cause the screen to print out. The printed copy will then be attached to the front of the batch of documents just closed.
CC AMBLK, AFTER CC AMCLS.

In the case of the above referenced command code, the data stored by the computer will include the TIN, MFT, and tax period of the ﬁrst closing in the block, the TIN, MFT, tax period (TPD) and the DLN of the last closing in the block. In addition the data also includes the Total Assessments, Total Credits and Total Audit results for the block of closings. CC AMBLK should be input after entering a batch of long closings on a particular terminal. Applies to NMF long closings, only.

minus if negative amount.
Total Credits - 4 to 18 positions, dollars and cents with $, decimal point and commas, right justiﬁed to include sign (-) if negative amount.

After the last DLN, Total Audit Results, Total Assessments and Total credits appear on the screen in response CC AMBLK, the terminal operator will depress the “PRINT” key which will cause the screen to print out. The printed copy will then be attached to the front of the batch of NMF long closings just completed.
